column3: Old Persian, Avestan, Vedic all show SOV
VO was dominant, compared to OV, by the 9th century (West, Some Notes on Word Order in Old and Middle English)
Proto-Germanic was SOV, and OV was dominant in early Old English  (West, Some Notes on Word Order in Old and Middle English)
GM&R entry for `Runic'. Braunmueller, Syntaxtopologische Studien zum Germanischen, 1982 (p. 139). Later North Germanic (Old Norse) was SVO.
Old Norse was SVO (Nygaard, Norron Syntax, 1905; cited in Haugan, Old Norse Word Order and Information Structure (2000, Dissertation, Trondheim).
Old Norse was SVO (Nygaard, Norron Syntax, 1905; cited in Haugan, Old Norse Word Order and Information Structure (2000, Dissertation, Trondheim).
